intro: Isoglossa oreacanthoides, commonly known as the mountain beardtongue, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of North America. It belongs to the family Boraginaceae and is characterized by its hairy, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its rugged appearance. Isoglossa oreacanthoides is often found in meadows, open woods, and along streambanks at higher elevations.
